description.narrative:
Den Somaliska Stabilitetsfonden (Somalia Stability Fund) är en innovativ fond som för samman Storbritannien, Danmark, Norge, Nederländerna och Förenade Arabemiraten. Stabilitetsfonden syftar till att finansiera projekt i Somalia för att stödja mer representativt och lyhört samhällsstyre på lokal nivå, samt stödja att konflikter får en fredlig lösning. Fonden finansierar främst projekt i speciellt utsatta områden av Somalia där Sveriges andra program vanligen har svårt att nå ut. Genom ett gediget upphandlingsförfarande har Adam Smith International kontrakterats som fondförvaltare.
Insatsen leds av Storbritannien (DFID) eftersom de är den största bidragsgivaren och dessutom håller kontraktet med fondförvaltaren. Eftersom fondförvaltaren är ett privat företag och Storbritannien inte ingår legalt bindande avtal med andra länder utan att dessa godkänns av brittiska parlamentet kommer Sida ingå ett Delegerat Samarbetesarrangemang (Arrangement on Delegated Cooperation) med DFID. Insatsen skulle i annat fall omöjliggöras.

The Somalia Stability Fund is a donor driven fund currently supported by United Kingdom, Denmark, Norway, Netherlands and United Arab Emirates). The aim of the fund is to provide sustained support over the longer term to local processes of building stability in Somalia, and to help areas become stable over the medium-term whilst building their linkages to a national framework. It seeks to be flexible, and to respond to the context as it evolves, addressing priorities and approaches set out by local stakeholders. The Stability Fund aims to address the security, development and political drivers of conflict in local areas to achieve the following outcomes: i) Legitimate, viable governance structures able to make and enforce rules locally; ii) Existing and emerging conflicts brought to conclusion and risks of future conflicts mitigated.
Through a thorough procurement procedure Adam Smith International was identified as Fund Manager for the Fund.
The United Kingdom (DFID) took the initiative for the fond and is therefore holding the contract with the Fond Manager. Since the Fond Manager is a private company and the UK does not enter into legally binding agreements with other states without parliamentary approval, Sida will sign an Arrangement on Delegated Cooperation with DFID for this intervention. The support would otherwise be impossible.

description.narrative: Providing immediate benefits to vulnerable populations in areas newly recovered from Al Shabaab – the Stability Fund has made a major contribution to the Federal Government’s Stabilisation Plan, supporting reconstruction projects in eight districts across Jubbaland and South West states and Middle Shebelle, including construction and rehabilitation of government buildings, roads, clinics, solar lights, water wells and support to livelihoods. - Conflict resolution – The Fund has supported a range of conflict resolution approaches, including grassroots training for elders, community representatives and local government officials to support them to broker community peace agreements; and a partnership with the Government of Puntland to facilitate a peace conference and construct five boreholes targeting areas affected by conflict over water scarcity. Overall, since inception, the Fund has supported the resolution of 485 conflicts. - Support to state formation – the Stability Fund has financed the processes that led to the formation of three emerging federal member states - South West, Galmudug and Hirshebelle – as well as the Jubbaland constitution-drafting process. These are essential building blocks of the federal state in Somalia, and, although imperfect, provide a basis on which to build towards greater inclusion, popular participation and representation. - Support to the core functions of government – following on from state formation, the Stability Fund has supported Jubbaland, South West and Galmudug to set up Ministries of Finance and Civil Service Commissions from scratch, enabling international standard systems for public financial management and recruitment of civil servants to be implemented. This has paved the way for World Bank recurrent costs financing to be provided at the sub-national level for the first time. - Address the economic and social drivers of conflict – the Fund has invested in employment intensive works schemes in five locations of Jubbaland; supported construction of six youth centres across Somalia designed and managed by young Somalis; boosted youth livelihoods through investments in the agriculture sector in Middle Shebelle and the fisheries sector in Kismayo; and enabled young entrepreneurs to access finance, incentivizing development of financial products tailored to young entrepreneurs in the process. In total, almost 15,000 young people have benefitted from educational or economic opportunities through SSF projects. - Community-government engagement in basic service delivery – our flagship project in Baidoa has delivered community infrastructure such as clinics, schools, roads and water projects, through a close working relationship with the South West ministries of Health, Education and Public Works. Similar projects are now underway in four locations of Galmudug. And in Puntland SSF has installed 1,374 solar street lights in six towns, in close collaboration with city councils and local administrations.
